review:
Reading other player's reviews and opinions I was expecting a way worse game, but this is great. Granted it took me close to an hour of tinkering to make it work, but with dgvoodoo2 the experience has been flawless until now. Just turn up the gamma ingame after installing dgvoodoo if it makes it darker, like it happened in my case. 
First impressions: the 3d world is very detailed and the best part is the camera that has total freedom, ie you can look under a bed, in a trashcan, essentially anything from any angle. It's kinda gimmicky to move it around, but a couple feature makes it easier (default cameras for every room, auto inspect etc).
Gone is the omni-click from GK2 that summed up every possible action and instead here for every object you have a list of different possible actions (look, open/close, pickup, talk, operate, use, think etc). The town I'm in now seems fully explorable and pretty big. It seems the kind of game that rewards observant, thorough players. It started very well. Also Tim Curry is back.

[table][th]
Review by [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34633003-Gaming-Masterpieces/lists/] Gaming Masterpieces [/url]  - The greatest games of all time on Steam. 
[/th][/table]

If you are just interested in point and click adventures go here: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43642699-The-Adventure-Library/lists/][u] The Adventure Library [/u][/url]

Is this game a masterpiece? Nooooo, this adventure is as bad as everyone says.

Unsolvable puzzles without real connection to the story (how to obtain the cat hair was not the worst!) and an awful user interface make this game borderline unplayable. I still finished it in over 20 hours, using a walkthrough frequently and wondering how someone could design such an atrocity. A large part of the game consists of reading puzzles and then placing and connecting points on a map... no idea how anyone could guess this, although one of my friends actually told me he liked that part.

There are certainly good aspects as well, like the professional speech and the well-written dialogues. Even the cutscenes are nice, and the game is quite long as well. I enjoyed the last part, when you were finally down in the underground temple with its fiendish deathtraps. Sierra certainly did invest money in the production. The 3D visuals look awful today, but they were state of the art for 1996 and somehow gave me a fuzzy feeling remembering my younger days (or other, better games from that time).

[u][b] Conclusion:[/b][/u]
One of the point and click adventures that nearly managed to kill the whole point and click adventure genre. Recommended only for game historians!

If this problem does not get resolved, then I will be filing a lawsuit over them for selling a defective product, and I suggest you to do the same. author: {'steamid': '76561199279783769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1670263626}
review:
Final game in the Gabriel Knight series and it's one from the time when they thought every game should have 3D graphics just because it was the latest thing regardless of whether it actually looked good or not. (Spoiler: it doesn't.) That aside, gameplay-wise, it's probably the best concept for 3D point & click adventures that was ever used. You freely control the camera and except for the rather cumbersome inventory, everything plays well and quickly.

The puzzles are mostly alright, but as a franchise staple, the game suffers from hardly ever telling you or even hinting at what you are currently supposed to do or what problems you are able to solve at the moment. It uses a semi-real-time-system with progressing time-slots in which things happen according to a scripted schedule, which keeps the gameworld fresh, but also means walking to and fro all the locations over and over again to check where something new is going on without, of course, any indication for where you should check for the most part. It also means you sometimes have to hunt for the one specific action that is still required to complete a time slot and that you can miss certain events, clues, pieces of evidence and dialogue.

The story is once again pretty good. The way it mixes history, mythology and local scenery into a fantastic tale is captivating and while it has supernatural aspects, it's great you spend most of your time with scientific research and regular events. The Gabriel Knight series is marketed as a horror series, but it's more like you play as someone who reads a horror novel than someone who engages much with any horror elements directly.

Unfortunately, the title giving protagonist is almost unbearable. He was always a tongue-in-cheek American douchebag stereotype joke, but with the sarcastic charme and goofiness that makes you like him anyways. In the previous games, though, he was never outright unlikable and grotesquely sleazoid like in this one. He comes across as that pervy uncle who remarks on how much his underage niece has grown in all the right places since last he saw her and is outright mean and condescending towards people. I don't understand why Tim Curry's voice acting for this is being praised so much, either, as he speaks almost every line in the same please-punch-me-in-the-face tone and mostly just sounds like a cross between a moron and a drunken creep harassing women at a bar. His performance alone kept me from enjoying the game as much as it otherwise deserves, but it's not just the voice overs but the awful lines they wrote for him, too.

Still, it's a great game and a classic for a reason. However, playing it on modern systems comes with a few difficulties, so better read about it in the forum here. One thing that's seriously annoying is how much the game crashes, so if you want to give it a try, remember to save your game regularly and frequently, because there's no auto-saving and the game crashes and freezes A LOT.

review:
The weakest Gabriel Knight game, but still a great time. Ironically has some of the BEST adventure game puzzles (the stuff Grace does on Sidney) and the infamously WORST one (the mustache and everything around it.) Very unique way of navigating the environment from before everything became standardized, which works just fine and is charmingly experimental. The story is a fun blend of vampires and Christian apocrypha and murder with a ton of history, the Jane Jensen special. The last section is a little weak, with a bunch of deathtraps out of nowhere, but that's nothing new for Gabriel Knight games, and the rest is strong enough to make up for it.

Worst thing of course is that "out of the box" on Steam the game will simply not work on modern operating systems. You will need to 
1.) Set up a virtual CD drive if you computer doesn't have one 
2.) Download and setup a third party program (DGVoodo2) to make it run
It's pretty awful and someone should really do something about it. 

TL;DR
A flawed, but great adventure game that is absolutely worth playing, but the hoops that Steam and even GOG require you to jump through to get it to run are really crappy. Solid recommendation, but I totally get if the work you have to do to even play it is too much for you, especially with plenty of other great adventure games that run just fine out there!

author: {'steamid': '76561198137563599', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1660713240}
review:
Firstly -> The game as is on steam is unplayable. There are several guides both here and online to help getting it running, without them you will get stopped by the game requiring a game disk or else graphical errors that make it unplayable. Honestly unreal that this game was uploaded as it is and allowed to be sold at this price.

That aside, this game is.... alright. I wish I could give this game a "meh" instead of a yes/no. I played this after playing GK1 and GK2 and imo this is the worst of the bunch. 

The graphics and controls make it really difficult to navigate and most of the puzzles and obstacles are impossible without a guide. The story felt unfinished, too many elements that went no where, most of the time the story is just characters explaining whats happening to each other and left me confused. The story needed editing and focus, by the time I reached the final day I was tangled in knots trying to keep track of everything being introduced. The main goal is supposed to be to find a kidnapped baby and every character drops it to learn local history and look for treasure, its very confusing. The characterisation is the worst of the three as well, Gabriel is insufferable and not in a fun way. Grace lost her character growth from the previous game. Mosely is there, terrible.

However - there were some genuinely enjoyable puzzles, very fun campy moments, and the fmvs are delightful in how over the top and silly they are. The ending was beyond silly, which had me howling with laughter and made the game worth it. The historical and historical fiction facts packed in are very interesting on their own, the computer system is very ambitious and fun despite feeling underdeveloped, the sheer amount of actions and dialouge and scenes is still impressive despite this game being over 20 years old. There is a lot to enjoy here.

If you are a fan of the series or this era of point and click its worth a playthrough for these experiences, otherwise its not worth the slog.

Столько всего намешали в одну корзину, похоже на салат из всего что осталось дома - заговоры, религия, какие-то вампиры, иллюминаты, пришельцы, я все и не вспомню. Порой сидишь такой втыкаешь в точку, и размышляешь: хули вообще происходит. Ну да ладно: как обычно, водянистая часть, оооо игре. Итак, мы играем за мужицкого пацана которого зовут - Night, Gabriel Night, он вроде как частный сыщик, ну знаете вот эти вот все ваши и мои Шерлоки Холмсы, а не, стопе, иногда мы играем еще и за его давнюю подругу. Короче не так сильно важно. Мы приезжаем в маленький городок, в поисках очень мелкого дитя некого принца Джеймса, просто его похитили, и вот этот "предок короля" нас нанял для этого. Вооот. Все это гласит что мы будем занимать детектив делами, потом еще и окажется что не все так просто и тд и тп

2) Классика. Ну как бы можно ознакомиться, много где читал что это чуть ли не лучший квест.

3) Персонажи. Почти все персонажи интересные. Они вам небезразличны, вызывают различные эмоции, в основном они выбешивают, а близкое окружение главного героя радует.

4) Диалоги и юмор. Начну с диалогов. Почти всегда если персонажи интересны то и диалоги являются таковыми. Эта игра не исключение. Очень часто гг-шка юморит и в диалогах, и просто когда вы в очередной раз не правильно решаете головоломку в своем странном стиле, это прикольно и забавно. Но хочу отметить, что часто встречаются игры, где диалоги сильнее.

[h1]Плохое:[/h1]

1) Техническая часть. Вообще я обычно не затрагиваю ее, потому как не считаю это важным. Тут это не сделать будет действительно преступлением. Как мы знаем старые игры очень часто ведут себе херовенько на новых пк, вот это поворот, конечно. Сейчас я поведаю вам свои все проблемы которые, скорее всего, будут вас ожидать и те с которыми столкнулся лично. И начнем пожалуй с запуска, ооо жесть. После установки игры, игра по обычаю должна запускаться через ярлычок или через знаменательную клавишу играть в стиме. Каково же было мое изумление когда на экране появилась надпись Insert CD 1, презрительно посмотрев на свой DVD привод, я понял что у меня его вообще как бы нет, он не работает с момента покупки. Да и вообще что за нахуй? Какой еще CD ты от меня требуешь? Да еще и первый, их что два? Спойлер - 3. Немного подумав я вооружившись минилопатой и вполне себе обыкновенной кружкой чая обнаружил файлик который следовало заменить в папке с игрой, что бы этой хрени не было. Замечательно. Захожу в игру: Во-первых, все лагает что эти 5фпсов плакать будут. Во-вторых, на экране квадрат. В-третьих, нет локализации, в квесте без субтитров, ахуенно. Это потом я уже обнаружил что субтитры есть просто они как то включаются странно в настройках, я не догадался сразу. Да даже если бы и догадался их прочитать не всегда успеваешь. Поэтому, собрав все личности было принято решение исправлять эти три "во-первых". Первое "во-первых" я исправил установив вуду, погоди-погоди dgVooDoo, только эту херобобу не так уж и просто запустить, перебрав все различные ddl она внезапно запустилась, да еще и с нужным разрешением, фантастика, подумал я. Два пука, ой, два пункта одним махом, мне словно перст исправляющий игры дали, только после середины игры понял, что мне вышло это боком, но об этом позже. С третьим "во-первых" вышло сложнее. Очень долго рыскав по интернету я так и не нашел руссификатор, который бы поставился на стим версию, почему? Да хрен его знает, я вообще не понимаю логику происходящего. Потом параллельно играя и продолжая искать великий и могучий руссич. Я нахожу сборки установщиков с русским языком. Поставил, ха, это херата, так же требует CD1, это уже не смешно? И самое интересное, замена ехешника не помогает. Так бле, пошли за образами, скачал три образа трех дисков. Перед каждым запускам запуская нужный. Установив снова вуду и попробовав установить руссификатор звука. И знаете что? На эту версию встал руссификатор звука, ЧТО ЗА ПЗД? Запускаю, помните я говорил, что играл параллельно? Сохранения тут не запускаются, просто Ваааау. Вуаля играю, хе-хе-хе, Нееее, стойте, я же говорил что разрешение вышло мне боком. Так вот, смотри, оказывается при широкоформатном разрешении, багается компьютер Сидней, и в нем если ты первый раз зашел в него в широкойформе, ты не сможешь открыть почту - НИКОГДА, просто НИКОГДА. Даже если менять разрешение обратно, а с этим багам ты не сможешь открыть письмо, а значит не сможешь разгадать загадку, даже если подсмотришь в интернуте. Эта игра просто имба, когда сражаешься против своих нервов. Крч, я скачал сохранения, благо какой-то дядя знал что может такое случиться. Ну если я все правильно помню, больше проблем не было, потом прошел игру.

2) Графика. Кто-нибудь ожидал другого? Минимум полигонов максимум пикселов.

3) Геймплей. Ничего особенного, курсором тыкаем по экрану в поисках взаимодействий. Но тут это не главное поэтому следующий пункт.

4) Головоломки и понимание, что делать. Хрен разберешь куда идти и что делать, если бы не гайды ходил бы я часами туда-сюда не понимаю что делать. Чтоб вы знали, читаю куда идти приходу делаю и даже после этого в голове вопрос, а почему? Зачем? И главное в чем логика? И такое происходит почти всю игру. Да мне говорили на эту тему, что вот дескать очень старая игра там так, но на днях я прошел The Longest Journey - и там было почти всегда все понятно.

[h1]Итого 3/10[/h1]

Таак, Я уверен что есть многие кому она зайдет или же те у кого играет ностальгия. Но сейчас получить от нее удовольствие от неподготовленного человека будет сложно. Да я даже не уверен что кто-то будет прорываться через все эти трудности что бы в нее сыграть все же. Мне она не понравилась и рекомендовать ее не могу, но тот кто не обращает внимания на графику, любит квесты и классику и готов побороться запуском, вперед можете попробовать.

[i]PS: Данный обзор это субъективное мнение, вы можете с ним соглашаться или не соглашаться, такое будет всегда, пока не поймете этого, что каждый человек имеет свое мнение и вкусы, будет довольно тяжко (читать очень быстро будто хотите скрыть это как мелкий шрифт при оформлении кредитов или кроссовер)[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198990784417', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1750, 'last_played': 1623094698}
review:
[h1] Gabriel Knight 3: Blut der Heiligen, Blut der Verdammten [/h1]

1999 wurde der dritte Teil der Gabriel Knight Reihe veröffentlicht. Ich würde empfehlen die Teile in der richtigen Reihenfolge zu spielen, da sich sonst dem Spieler einige Dinge und Zusammenhänge nicht vollständig erschließen.  

[b] Geschichte und Charaktere: [/b]     
Gabriel Knight ist ein Privatdetektiv für das Übernatürliche, ein Schattenjäger. Zudem ist er auch Buchautor. Im ersten Teil ermittelte Gabriel in New Orleans in der Voodoo-Szene, im zweiten Teil jagte Gabriel in Deutschland einen Werwolf. Diesmal verschlägt es den Schattenjäger nach Frankreich. 

Gabriel hat den Auftrag das entführte Kind eines Prinzen zu finden und zu retten. Seine Ermittlungen führen ihn in das französische Dorf Rennes-le-Château. Was haben eine Gruppe von Touristen, eine Schatzsuche in diesem Ort, der Heilige Gral, eine Blutlinie und mysteriöse Morde mit dieser Entführung zu tun? Diesmal muss sich der Schattenjäger mit Vampiren auseinandersetzen. 

Unterstützung bekommt Gabriel dabei von seiner Assistentin Grace Nakimura und seinem Freund Mosley, der Polizist in New Orleans ist. Spielern und Fans sind die Charaktere aus den vorherigen Teilen bekannt. Mosley macht zufälligerweise Urlaub in Rennes-le-Château und nimmt an der Schatzsuche nach dem heiligen Gral teil. 

Gabriel und Grace sind spielbare Charaktere. 

[b] Technik und Steuerung: [/b]      
Bevor der Spielspaß losgeht, müssen noch folgende technische Hürden überwunden werden: 
[list] 
[*] [b] Deutsche Sprachausgabe: [/b] Um das Spiel mit deutscher Sprachausgabe spielen zu können, muss ein entsprechender Patch installiert werden. Hier ein Link dazu: https://www.compiware-forum.de/downloads/file/513-gabriel-knight-3-blood-of-the-sacred-blood-of-the-damned-german-patch/#overview 
[*] [b] CD1 einlegen: [/b] Bei einer Steam-Version ist das irgendwie schwierig eine CD einzulegen. Peinlich für Steam ist, dass sie sich selber gar nicht um das Problem und dessen Lösung bemühen. Gog hat für das Problem allerdings eine Lösung. Hier der Link dazu: http://files.gog.com/support/GK3.zip 
[*] [b] Grafikprobleme: [/b] Ich habe die schlimmsten Grafikprobleme mit Hilfe der Anwendung “dgVoodoo” in den Griff bekommen. Allerdings blieben kleine Fehler, aber im Grunde war das Spiel so spielbar. Anhand meiner Screenshots lässt sich erkennen, dass das Spiel halbwegs passabel lief. 
[/list] 

Die Steuerung ist etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig, aber mit Hilfe der Anleitung im Spiel kann man zurechtkommen. Mit gedrückter linker Maustaste zoomen und dann per Click interagieren. Die Kamera-Einstellungen sind oftmals sehr unglücklich und verändern sich durch das Zoomen. Man kann über ein Menü die Kamera-Position neu ausrichten. 

[b] Grafik / Ton / Rätsel: [/b]     
Die Grafik ist sicherlich nicht die Schönste. Ich fand sie ehrlich gesagt schon 1999 genau so hässlich wie heute. Allerdings ist sie schon wieder so markant und einzigartig, dass es schon fast als Kunst durchgehen könnte. Modernere Titel sind grafisch nicht weniger hässlich. Man schaue sich nur “State of Mind” oder “Virgina” an. 

Die Musik ist 1a, ebenso wie bei den Vorgängern. Wenn man den Patch installiert hat, bekommt man auch eine vollständige deutsche Sprachausgabe. Nur Grace spricht einmal einen Satz in Englisch, wenn man sich ein Objekt im Inventar ansieht. Das wurde wohl vergessen zu übersetzen. Sonst bin ich mit der deutschen Sprachausgabe zufrieden und mir ist immer noch Gabriels “Neeeähey, das geht so nicht!” im Gehör. 

Die Rätsel decken das gesamte Spektrum ab. Von “an den Haaren herbeigezogen” bis genial ist alles dabei. Die Verkleidung für Gabriel zusammenstellen... na, ja das hätte man beim Rätsel-Designe besser lösen können und wohl müssen. Genial sind hingegen die SIDNEY-Rätsel (SIDNEY = Schattenjäger-Informations-Datenbank) und das Lösen des Rätsels “Le Serpent Rouge”. Die Rätsel sind teilweise sehr fordernd, aber zu bewältigen. Wer seine grauen Zellen schonen möchte, kann auch auf eine der diversen Komplettlösungen im Internet zurückgreifen. An manchen Stellen musste ich auch von einer Komplettlösung Gebrauch machen. 

[b] Geschichtlicher Hintergrund: [/b]     
Wie schon in Teil 2 fühlt sich das Spiel teilweise wie eine Geschichtsnachhilfestunde an. Ich fand es bereichernd und interessant. Andere finden es wohlmöglich öde. Der Besuch im Museum liegt eben nicht jedem, da scheiden sich die Geschmäcker. 

[b] Fan-Fiktion: [/b]
Selten habe ich mir für ein Spiel mehr eine Remastered-Version / Special Edition bzw. ein Remake gewünscht als für Gabriel Knight 3. Darüber hinaus würde ich mir eine Fortsetzung der Reihe wünschen. Vielleicht könnte Crazy Bunch zusammen mit Assemble Entertainment hier ein Reboot der Reihe realisieren? Mit der Sierra-Kult-Reihe "Larry" ist das dem deutschen Entwickler und Publisher Team sehr gut gelungen. Warum nicht auch mit der Sierra-Kult-Reihe "Gabriel Knight"? Ein vierter Teil wäre sicher ein Traum für alle Gabriel Knight Fans.

[b] Fazit: [/b]      
Meiner Meinung nach “storytechnisch” der stärkste Gabriel Knight Teil.  

Wer sich mit der Grafik und manchen Macken arrangieren kann, erhält unterm Strich eine gute Unterhaltung. Das Preis- Leistungsverhältnis ist mehr als fair. 

[b] Bewertung: [/b] 82 %

review: This is a very hard game to love if you aren't a fan of the series when you start.  While the developers took big chances - and saw big returns - with the first two games, the early decision to make the third game with rudimentary 3D graphics was an unfortunate mistake.  Regardless of the clunky interface and visuals, this game is one last chance to solve a mystery alongside our favorite Schattenjager, Gabriel Knight.  While Tim Curry returns to the lead role, his performance is filled with mockery and comes across poorly at times.  Still, the voice-work is strong overall, as is the music.  If you enjoyed other games in the series, this one deserves your time - but don't start here and expect to know what's going on.

review:
J'avais adoré ce 3eme opus de la série et malgré les commentaires, j'ai donc tenté le coup lors d'une remise.
Contrairement à de nombreux joueurs, je n'ai pas eu de problème au lancement ni de bug en cours de route.
A vous de voir, donc, si vous prenez le risque.

Côté jeu, un régal de retrouver Gabriel et Grace dans cette intrigue palpitante, bien ficelée, qui sait éviter la linéarité et l'accumulation de casse-tête au détriment du scénario qu'on retrouve sur de nombreux point & click plus récents. 
Une vraie enquête, donc avec des énigmes parfois très ardues (d'autant qu'il est difficile de trouver des soluces approfondies quand on sèche vraiment), le tout sur fond d'occultisme autour du mystère du trésor de Rennes le Château
A noter que le jeu est en anglais non sous titré ce qui ne facilite pas la tache.

Bien sûr, le graphisme va paraître d'un autre temps aux plus jeunes mais si vous passez outre, vous apprécierez la reconstitution très fidèle des lieux (Rennes le Château et ses environs), la documentation historique très complète avec un bon vieux complot mélangeant Templiers, Egypte ancienne, Saint Graal etc et une qualité de scénario comme on en voit rarement dans ce type de jeux actuellement. Les personnages, même secondaires, sont intéressants, on retrouve l'humour inégalable de Gabriel et le sérieux de Grace (vous les incarnez tour à tour comme dans les épisodes précédents). Plus de vidéo comme dans le 2, les créateurs faisaient leurs premiers pas dans la 3D (du coup ça pique un peu évidemment).

Un grand classique à faire ou à refaire

review: Cozy, atmosphere rich and intriguing. Gabriel Knight 3 is set in a small village in France where you as Gabriel and Grace are investigating the abduction of an infant child. With an interface not seen in any other major point-n-click adventure (to my knowledge) where you hover around like a drone camera you can really immerse yourself in the environments of the game while investigating with great accuracy, As far as adventure games go, this game has it all, the plot is like any good Agatha Christie novel mixed with occult and religious elements. Add to this, extremely well done voice acting which made me laugh so many times, and great puzzles and a gallery of memorable characters, this game will make you want to check in to a hotel in rural France asap and start looking for clues and interrogating hotel guests. And yes, the music is amazing and superbly fits the game world. This game is one of my all time favorites, but you will probably need a open mind, if you start playing it in 2020. Please do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035354638', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1602557913}
review:
I bought this when I owned my previous computer. The textures were broken and the game locked up before I could get out of the first area. Not a great first impression.

When I got my new computer, I reinstalled the game and tried it out again. Now it's asking me for a CD. I went to the Steam message boards to see if there was a quick fix, but the solution involved grabbing an altered executable from GOG. And because the game folder's read-only and Windows has decided I don't have the privileges to change read-only status, all I had to do was log in as administrator, uncheck the "read-only," download software from another company's website, and then, and then...

Nah. NAHHHHH. For Gabriel Knight THREE? The worst game in the series? Nah. This is already too much effort. I'd expect these kinds of work-arounds if I were trying to run the game off of my old CDs from 1999, but for a digital version still being sold in 2020? This game should be ready to play on install.

You realize that for $6 I could've bought 20 McNuggets and had my choice of dipping sauces? You don't even get barbecue sauce with Gabriel Knight 3. Not even sweet and sour. And I wouldn't need to run tech support on my nuggies - they'd be ready for the end user right out of the takeout bag. Wouldn't have to steal honey mustard from Wendy's and double-fry them to make them edible. I'd just open up the box and enjoy.

But if you're, like, really big on the whole IKEA "some assembly required" thing and either really loved this game as a kid or have a hard-on for vampires and ugly, blocky, late-90s 3D models, then I *guess* this might be up your alley?

But seriously, don't buy this broken-ass version of a bad game. Consider either getting it on GOG or forgetting about GK3 entirely and going to McDonald's.

review: Sin duda uno de mis juegos favoritos desde que lo jugué a finales de los 90 y que hizo que me enganchara a las aventuras gráficas. Lo tiene todo: personajes interesantes, movilidad en el juego y sobre todo una historia fascinante que conforme la vas desentramando se revela como algo muy muy especial. El mejor trabajo de Jane Jensen hasta el momento. Tengo el juego desde que lo compré y desde entonces lo he jugado varias veces porque siempre hay algo que se me pasa, por eso nunca he conseguido tener el máximo de puntuación! A pesar de tener el juego físicamente no lo podía jugar en mi PC porque ya no es compatible pero en vez de usar un programa para poder usarlo me decidí a comprarlo en Steam. Pero la verdad es que ha sido bastante decepcionante la experiencia porque aparte de que no está en castellano y sí que se publicó en castellano en la plataforma no lo tienen. Además, para poder jugar sin que se bloquee y funcione tienes que jugar con la calidad más baja de gráficos y es una pena porque a pesar de ser en 3D el entorno del juego estaba muy logrado y te permite ver a tu alrededor 360°. Steam debería poner a la venta juegos que se puedan jugar de la misma manera en los ordenadores actuales que para eso es una plataforma de juegos y tienen la capacidad de hacerlo o que no lo pongan. En fin, aparte de esto, el juego es simplemente espectacular. Te engancha desde el primer minuto. La historia trata esta vez sobre el mito Santo Grial que se cree escondido en el sur de Francia, en Rennes le Chateau, lugar que existe y que el juego recrea estupendamente. Llevo años queriendo ir a visitar los sitios en los que se ambienta el juego!!! Gabriel se ve envuelto en el secuestro de un niño, hijo de un aristócrata escocés, perpetrado por un siniestro grupo que resultan ser vampiros y que quieren al niño por su especial sangre. Gabriel es ayudado de nuevo por Grace y entre ellos la relación se estrecha aún más y la tensión es palpable lo que le da al juego una capa emocional a parte del guion de la historia. Es un juego extremadamente difícil pero la interfaz creada por Grace y Sydney da un toque nuevo y diferente al juego lo que hace que a pesar de la dificultad, cuando avanzas te sientes sumamente orgullo de haberlo hecho porque  no es nada fácil, sobre todo con el tema del manuscrito de Le Serpent Rouge. En definitiva, un juego indispensable que da horas de entretenimiento. El final es muy bueno también. Una única pega, en el juego se puede morir al final y yo, ODIO que se pueda morir en un juego!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040396418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1599541414}
review:
Gabriel Knight 3 is credited with killing adventure games. Now, I see where it's coming from. A lot of puzzles in this game are bad. Really bad. The "cat hair moustache" puzzle has become the golden example of "moon logic" in videogames. However, with the simple addition of a gamefaqs guide, you'll find that GK3 is not just an excellent game, but an amazing one. 

First of all, Tim Curry is back as the voice of Gabriel. You wouldn't believe the difference it makes, the man could carry the entire game on his back with his acting. The voice acting in general is very good, and really pulls you into the story.

The story? God. Gabriel knight has always been about secret societies, conspiracies and the occult, but this is the biggest one yet. We're not talking about some rinky-dink vodoo cult in New Orleans or some kraut werewolves in munich. This game deals with a far reaching, worlwide level web of conspiracies and secret societies dating back thousands of years, with immense consequences. 
You might be mistaken by the title in thinking that this game is about vampires, but the vampires are just one of the many factions and people looking for the treasure hidden in France. Most characters in the game are looking for that treasure, and they are all hiding secrets. 

Gabriel Knight 3 is built in such a way that you can finish the game without finding out a lot of these secrets, with quite a few missable moments and clues, and some almost insane puzzles (we're talking geometry and shit here) that you'd be hard pressed to figure out on your own. Thankfully, a guide is still useful here, and if you follow one you'll slowly but surely find out just how big the conspiracy is, and the secrets of those you know (and don't know), and the ending will not just blow you away, but make perfect sense while it happens. 

After the disappointment of GK2, GK3 might just be the best one in the series, and this is no exaggeration. If you liked the other games, or hell, even if you just like adventure games, don't sleep on this one. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031136567', 'num_games_owned': 1441, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1597243133}
review:
[h1] Developed and published by the legendary Sierra On-Line GK3 is still, to this day, an innovative and unique adventure game worth experiencing. [/h1]

Written and designed by the veteran of the genre, [b] Jane Jensen [/b], "Blood of the Sacred, Blood of the Damned" takes place after the events of the stellar "The Beast Within" and follows Gabriel Knight (again voiced by the legendary [b] Tim Curry [/b]) on a trip to France to track down the kidnapped child of Albany's prince Charles whose bloodline, accidentaly, holds many mysteries... Throughout the 13+ hour-long campaign, there are multiple twists & turns along with witty dialogue and interesting characters to meet.

As far as the gameplay goes - it's the usual point-and-click type of a game, but with clever additions to the genre. Whereas "Sins of the Fathers" was a traditional point-and-click and "The Beast Within" a groundbreaking FMV adventure, "Blood of the Sacred, Blood of the Damned" employs a fully 3D rendered world and characters with a [b] free-moving camera [/b] (something I've not seen replicated in any of the future PNC games I've played). What this means is that you'll be able to, [i] using directional keys [/i], move around every corner of the location your character's in and explore every nook and cranny looking for hidden compartments and items. Sometimes this might seem overwhelming considering the sizes of certain locations, but it rarely devolves into [i] pixel-hunting [/i]. However, it does provide for a very dynamic gameplay loop and I loved the fact that you didn't have to watch your character walk from one end of the map to another because when you move the camera all the way to the door/exit, your character would be, for the lack of a better word, be [i] teleported [/i] right next to it - saving you, what might end up being, hours of your time. What this game also adds to the series is scripted events which only take place at a certain time so you might miss out on certain (optional) events if you're not careful enough. Thankfully, the game doesn't punish you for not having all the information or missing some of these events, so you don't have to constantly restore your save files to get that one dialogue you missed. While I'm on the point of information-gathering, there is also a laptop, which aids you in the more complex puzzles the game offers, called SIDNEY. SIDNEY has the ability to translate, analyze, print etc. your clues which you feed into her (like license plates, fingerprints, photos, maps and audio-tapes). A large part of the game revolves around you solving the riddle of the "Red Serpent" which is this huge 13-part collection of notes which helps you locate a certain tomb. This is done, mostly, through reading the cryptic passages, searching the internet for keywords, getting secret codes from paintings and mapping it all onto the map of the place you're in. This is the only part of the game where I felt frustration because of certain clues not being clear enough so I ended up placing markers on the map on what I thought were the right spots, but due to the nature of the text, I placed them horizontally, instead of vertically, and I had to look up the exact part online. Anyways, despite my frustrations with it, it is a unique puzzle that makes you feel like a true adventurer while you're doing it.

Technically, the game ran smooth for me most of the time. Keep in mind, I didn't try running it vanilla. I only started it after I had set up DgVoodoo and changed the resolution to 1920x1080 so my graphics were incredibly sharp and the game looked gorgeous. The only problem that I've encountered was the E-mail section of the laptop. There's a point, near the end of the game, where you have to access an E-mail to progress, but every time I opened the E-mail tab - it was blank. I found out that this was due to my 1080p setup and the E-mails were actually showing out of the screen and were unclickable. Due to this, I had to download a save file - which was in native resolution - access the E-mail from there and then just quickly set up the resolution back and it was smooth sailing from there on out.

[b] All in all, if you're a fan of adventure games in general, I really don't think you'll want to miss out on this one. [/b] Each GK game is standalone, so if any of them seem particularly interesting, you can just play them in any order - the only thing you'll be missing out on is a couple of references to prior events. However, I would not recommend this one to beginners of the genre due to its complex narrative and highly ambitious UI. If you're looking to get into the genre with GK games, I would then recommend "The Beast Within", which is also my most favourite of the trilogy. That's it. Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198121755878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3425, 'last_played': 1555784960}
review:
Outstanding game! Outstanding series! If you enjoy the classic point-n-click, give this one a shot. If you like it, try the other two games. If not, move on. 

Rather than writing separate reviews for each game, I'm going to briefly cover the entire series in a few paragraphs. 

With their love/hate, yin/yang, brain vs. brawn relationship, Gabriel and Grace steal the show! I can tell series' creator Jane Jensen really enjoyed using this to spruce up the character cohesion and back-n-forth banter. In my opinion, this is by far the most enjoyable aspect of the series. 

The stories themselves are predictable, but enjoyable. You probably won't find anything original or out of the ordinary here. The characters were always interesting though, so what they were doing and why they were doing it wasn't a huge deal for me. I will say that Jane and the dev team did a lot of research for each game's setting. Some players may be turned off by the historical and cultural detail, usually found in game texts or conversations. On the contrary, I enjoyed learning about the cultural history of New Orleans Voodoo in GK1, the Ludwig/Wagner relationship in GK2, and the Rennes le Chateau mystery of France in GK3. Yes, there were artistic liberties taken by the devs here. Unless you are an expert in these areas, I highly doubt those liberties will adversely affect your enjoyment of the games. 

The soundtrack for all three games are well-done. I even unexpectedly caught myself humming a few of the common tunes throughout the days I played the series. 

The art/graphics of each game are different.  Keep in mind, all three games are based on 90s technology, so don't expect a post-2000 experience.  GK1 has the classical 2-D characters and backgrounds at low resolution.  Following the trend in the mid-90s, GK2 was a full FMV game with realistic screen captures.  GK3 broke from both molds and placed the player in an animated 3-D world in which camera control becomes the primary exploration device.   I played these games back to back to back, and the graphical switch was a little jarring.   However, it didn't take long to get adjusted and focus on the game itself.

The gameplay of GK1 was what you would expect of an early 90's point-n-click. However, what I didn't expect was the tremendous dialogue/text detail given to each and every background object. Player beware... that group of seemingly uninteresting pixels in a group of 20 other uninteresting pixelated room objects may very well be the key to solving a puzzle. This was initially a source of frustration for me in GK1. Once I accepted it for what it was and adapted my approach to exploration, things went much smoother. Mostly because of the improved graphics, the 2nd and 3rd installments of the series are much more forgiving when it comes to background objects. 

Regarding the basic inventory puzzles, I never caught myself thinking "That makes no sense whatsoever..." during the Gabriel Knight series. There were a few puzzles that require some out-of-the-box thinking, but the rest made sense. This was a nice break from wacko logic that dictates many classic adventure games. When something changes in the story, even something you may deem of little consequence, revisit old areas and retry actions again. Keep this in mind if you get stuck (especially in The GK2). I'm guessing this was a complaint for the first two games, because GK3 does a great job in cluing the player in regarding time-related event changes. 

Finally, each game has at least one difficult puzzle that requires attention to detail to previous in-game events, forethought, planning, and trial and error. Jane and the dev team did an excellent job with these, especially the Le Serpent Rouge puzzle of GK3. That one was masterful!! However subtle, the games give you the clues you need. It's up to you to put the pieces together. 

The Gabriel Knight series is overlooked or ignored on many of the "Best of..." lists for adventure gaming. Even though some some critics may think it wasn't worthy of high accolades, I believe it well mixed most of the ingredients classic adventure gamers love in the genre. I was always looking forward to getting home from work and spending a few more hours with Gabriel and Grace.

review:
Loved this game as a young boy. I still love it, a great story and atmosphere. 

This version of the game is filled with crashes, glitches and graphical problems. In my honest opinion: this is the hardest game of the whole GK - series.

Pros:
+ Total nostalgia 
+ Music and voice acting.  Music is magnificent, atmospheric and enjoyable. Voice acting by Tim Curry, pure gold.
+ A great story all in all
+ Unique atmosphere, Jane Jensen can write and create always something different.
+ Again a great Gabriel Knight game.
+ Some puzzles were great to solve - following with funny or interesting results.
+ Rennes-le-Château is a beautiful environment for this game, with spiced occultism and mysticism - it is great.
+ Moving the Camera
+ Great adventure game - one of my favourites.
+ Classic, even with now outdated graphics.


Cons:
- Very hard to play this version, because the game keeps crashing.
- Some puzzles were almost impossible (for me at least).
- Very flawed, this version contains high graphical errors.
- Constant crashing - it seems the game doesn't like Windows 10. 
- Outdated graphics- I had to play in software renderer mode.
- Technical problems are so high in this version, that I wont recommend to buy this, until 
   these are fixed.
- So, all in all. The greatest puzzle was when playing this version of the game: how much I 
  am able to proceed in story, before game crashing.

***/*****
[ 3/5 ]

review:
I would love to base this review on gameplay, but I have no way of knowing how this game plays because when I start it up it requests that I insert CD 1. Now, as you can well imagine, this presented me with quite a challenge since I do not own a CD copy of this game nor do I have a CD drive on my laptop. I do not blame the developers, because lord knows anyone involved in the making of this game is well out of the "business" by now. I have heard there are some arcane ways of getting this to work, installing some fake cd drive, inventing a time machine, watching the episodes of Frasier where the guy who played Gabriel in the second game makes various appearances, but I am of a mind that if I purchase a game it should work and this game does not and therefore should not be purchased. Go play the remake of the first game and possibly watch a play through of the second, because, lets face it, the second game would torment you for hours for not accidentally reading through every single line of text in a library

Update- And for some reason, years later, the game works. I think steam must have updated it's compatability because nothing has changed with my machine. The graphics are pretty bad, but I am amazed it even works with how hinky old school 3D is with modern computers. It's a Gabriel Knight game with Tim Curry doing voice work, what's not to like. You will most likely need a walkthrough for some puzzles that suffer from 90s moon logic.

review:
The game is really good, fueled by a strong and well-researched story, great voice-acting and strong characters. On the other hand, you have a rather weak game design (Game wont progress unless you read a number of historical references, which feels arbitrary and forces you to click every single hotspot in all available areas) and dreadfully outdated 3D graphics with laughable textures.

It does not take well to Windows 10 either. The game crashed constantly on me. Changing to software rendering fixed the problem and made it stable, but the already poor visuals suffers heavily.

All-in-all this is a great game, but the already mentioned problems requires a lot of good will from the player. Still well worth it for fans of the Gabriel Knight series though!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992860654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1472611450}
review: Amazing game, as great as the first two Gabriel Knights. Glad it is finally available in Steam along with the original GK1 and with GK2. Didn't play a lot of this version yet, but the GOG version doesn't run so well on modern computers. If that is the case here, I recommend using the dgVoodoo 2 tool to run it. But it didn't crash in my time with it and it felt a lot smoother than the GOG vanilla version. The game itself is brilliant, Jane Jensen at her best. The interface can be a bit obtuse at first, but I still find it very innovative and it feels natural after you get the hang of it. The plot borrows from some of the same sources that Dan Brown used in The Da Vinci Code (specially Holy Blood, Holy Grail), so expect your grail templar conspiracy here. But Jensen is a far superior writer and Knight is a far superior character. Grace, Gerde and Mosely are also back. The puzzles are nothing short of daunting, and in my opinion it is the toughest adventure game of all time if you are aiming for full points (and the full story). The game spans three days, divided by two hours periods, and a lot of the puzzles are time oriented, meaning you have to be at certain places at certain times to learn something or speak to someone. Others are just mind bending but, aside for a couple of unfair ones, they make perfect sense and you just have to pay a lot of attention to everything. One of my favourite games.
